FacilityName: Central Storage and Warehouse Company, Inc.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Overview and Regulated Substances

Central Storage & Warehouse Co. (CSW) is a public refrigerated warehouse 
company founded in 1949, operating multiple facilities in the state of Wisconsin. 
The CSW Madison plant provides dry, refrigerated and frozen storage and 
logistics services for manufacturers and commercial distributors. Food and food 
ingredients are the primary items handled. CSW employees are typically involved 
in the forklift unloading trucks and rail cars, placing items into storage, retrieving 
ordered items, and reloading transportation assets, as well as the administrative, 
supervisory, and maintenance functions in support of these operations. 
Approximately 22,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant at 
this location, circulating throughout the plant in a pressurized system.  Neither 
CSW personnel nor community members would be in contact with the ammonia 
except for certain planned maintenance functions or accidental release.

Chemical Release Prevention and Response

CSW is committed to providing a safe environment for its employees and 
neighbors, including the appropriate use and control of facility chemicals. It is the 
company's intent to fully comply with the EPA's Risk Management Program 
(RMP), Title 40 CFR 68, as well as OSHA's Process Safety Management 
Standard (PSM), Title 29 CFR 1910.119. CSW Madison promotes employee 
safety involvement and safety program continuous improvement through its 
Safety Committee and PSM Committee meetings. Senior management 
participates in safety program planning and monitoring.

CSW management and staff strive to reduce or eliminate chemical exposure 
risks through physical measures wherever feasible and communicate remaining 
risks to all employees and other interested individuals through training, signage, 
and cooperation with public safety agencies. Physical measures include the use 
of:
-	Safe process equipment
-	Appropriate construction

materials
-	Centralized processes away from employees, where possible
-	Pressure relief valves, check valves, and venting
-	Automatic process safety shutdown
-	Local and remote manual shutdown
-	Ammonia detection 
-	24-hour professional remote alarm monitoring
-	Appropriate facility signage to inform, remind, raise awareness, and speed 
response by employees, maintenance, visitors, and emergency personnel

Procedural methods include:
-	New employee and refresher awareness and response training
-	Continuous professional development of maintenance personnel including 
both routine maintenance and emergency training through the 
Refrigeration Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA) and other 
consulting and education sources
-	Mentoring of all new maintenance personnel by more experienced 
employees
-	Partnering with a private refrigeration firm for emergency response 
assistance
-	Partnering with public emergency response agencies including the fire 
department, hazardous response team, and local emergency planning 
commission to enhance preparedness through information sharing, 
walkthroughs, and facility familiarization
-	Review of system operations, maintenance, and safety by independent 
industry professionals
-	Review and update of maintenance and response procedures during 
Safety Committee and PSM Committee meetings
-	Written assessment and record keeping of changes 

Five-year Accident History

CSW Madison has had no reportable accidents in the previous five years.

Planned Changes

Maintenance training will continue to be a focus, with current maintenance 
employees seeking RETA certification as well as supplemental hazardous 
response training. CSW is also undertaking a review of record keeping 
procedures to make materials more accessible to system operators.  Facility 
and response plan familiarization with a private response company is planned 
to assist in critiquing preparedness and enhance response speed an

d 
effectiveness.  PPE requirements and supplies will be reviewed to ensure 
adequate equipment and procedures are in place.
